You see your logs.\n     This setup allows you to collect text logs from on-premises Windows machines and send them to Azure Log Analytics using Azure Arc. The data collection rule ensures the logs are\n     collected as per the defined paths, and the agent sends them to your Log Analytics workspace.\n@@ -236,7 +256,8 @@ The external user receives an email invitation to join your Microsoft Entra ID p\n \n By following these steps, you can securely open your Azure Log Analytics workspace to a user outside of your tenant, allowing them to access and query logs as needed.\n \n-## Next steps\n+## Useful Links\n \n - [Understand the Microsoft Entra private network connector](concept-connectors.md)\n - [Learn about Microsoft Entra Private Access](concept-private-access.md)\n+"
}. Please summarise it in a few sentences, using UK grammar and ensure the response is formatted for markdown. Do not start the response with here is summary.","role":"user"}
ai_summary.Response:
This commit updates the documentation for exporting Global Secure Access connector logs.

Key changes include:

*   **Refined instructions for setting up data collection:** The process for creating a custom log table has been updated to use the "New Custom Log (Direct Ingest)" method, which requires uploading a sample JSON log file.
*   **Clarified Data Collection Rule (DCR) setup:** The steps now guide users to select an existing DCR created during table creation, rather than creating a new one.
*   **Updated verification steps:** The instructions for checking data in Log Analytics have been revised to use Kusto Query Language (KQL) and specify a sample query.
*   **Renamed "Next steps" to "Useful Links":** This change aims to provide a clearer indication of the section's content.

ai_summary.Response:
This commit updates several documentation files related to Microsoft Entra ID. Key changes include:

*   **Error Code Documentation:** The `docs/identity-platform/reference-error-codes.md` file has been updated to correct a link in the AADSTS50124 error description and to add new error codes AADSTS240003 and AADSTS240004.
*   **Server Version Requirements:** Multiple files within the `docs/identity/hybrid/cloud-sync` and `docs/identity/hybrid/connect` directories have been updated to reflect a preference for Windows Server 2022, 2019, or 2016, shifting away from solely referencing Windows Server 2016 as the minimum. This includes updates to prerequisites for Microsoft Entra Connect, cloud sync agents, and provisioning agents.
*   **Date Updates:** Several `ms.date` metadata fields have been advanced to later dates, suggesting ongoing content reviews and updates.

Add the server to the same Active Directory forest as the users whose passwords you need to validate. If you *don't* intend to use password hash synchronization in conjunction with Pass-through Authentication, read the [Microsoft Entra Connect release notes](./reference-connect-version-history.md).\n \n-3. Identify one or more additional servers (running Windows Server 2016 or later, with TLS 1.2 enabled) where you can run standalone Authentication Agents. These additional servers are needed to ensure the high availability of requests to sign in. Add the servers to the same Active Directory forest as the users whose passwords you need to validate.\n+3. Identify another server that runs Windows Server 2022, Windows Server 2019, or Windows Server 2016 with TLS 1.2 enabled where you can run standalone Authentication Agents. These additional servers are needed to ensure the high availability of requests to sign in. Add the servers to the same Active Directory forest as the users whose passwords you need to validate.\n \n     >[!IMPORTANT]\n     >In production environments, we recommend that you have a minimum of 3 Authentication Agents running on your tenant. There's a system limit of 40 Authentication Agents per tenant. And as best practice, treat all servers running Authentication Agents as Tier 0 systems (see [reference](/windows-server/identity/securing-privileged-access/securing-privileged-access-reference-material))."

ai_summary.Response: The provided commit history indicates updates across several Microsoft Entra ID documentation pages, primarily concerning hybrid identity solutions. The changes focus on clarifying and standardising the supported Windows Server versions for agent installations and related prerequisites. Specifically, Windows Server 2022, 2019, and 2016 are now consistently listed as the recommended or supported operating systems for various hybrid identity components, including cloud sync agents and Microsoft Entra Connect installations. Additionally, some documentation dates have been updated to reflect the latest publication or review.

Phased rollout is on by default.\n+When the agent creates a new policy in report-only mode, the policy is rolled out in phases, so you can monitor the effect of the new policy. Phased rollout is on by default.\n \n-You can change the number of days between each phase by either dragging the slider or entering a number in the text box. The number of days between each phase is the same for all phases. Make sure you're starting the phased rollout with enough time to monitor the impact before the next phase starts and so the rollout doesn't start on a weekend or holiday, in case you need to pause the rollout.\n \n :::image type=\"content\" source=\"media/agent-optimization/phased-rollout-settings.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot of the phased rollout settings in the Conditional Access Optimization agent settings.\" lightbox=\"media/agent-optimization/phased-rollout-settings.png\":::\n \n@@ -146,15 +143,19 @@ There are several key points to consider regarding the identity and permissions\n \n - The agent runs under the identity and permissions of the *user who enabled the agent in your tenant*.\n - Avoid using an account that requires elevation through PIM for just-in-time elevation. ai_summary.Response: This commit updates documentation related to Microsoft Entra Conditional Access. Changes include refining the roles required for agent actions, clarifying the initial agent run process, and adjusting the wording around the agent's trigger and phased rollout settings. Additionally, a note about Azure DevOps no longer being covered by the Windows Azure Service Management API Conditional Access policy has been added, and some image files have been added and removed.

  "status": "modified",

  "changes": 19,
  "blob_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/blob/e27721ad0e55be77abc3d812ee599f1caf9a681b/docs%2Fidentity%2Fdevices%2Fhowto-vm-sign-in-azure-ad-windows.md",
  "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/e27721ad0e55be77abc3d812ee599f1caf9a681b/docs%2Fidentity%2Fdevices%2Fhowto-vm-sign-in-azure-ad-windows.md",
  "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fidentity%2Fdevices%2Fhowto-vm-sign-in-azure-ad-windows.md?ref=e27721ad0e55be77abc3d812ee599f1caf9a681b",
  "patch": "@@ -430,6 +430,25 @@ Try these solutions:\n \n   Sign in with the user account in a web browser. For instance, sign in to the [Azure portal](https://portal.azure.com) in a private browsing window. If you're prompted to change the password, set a new password. Then try connecting again.\n \n+### AADSTS293004: The target-device identifier in the request xxx was not found in the tenant xxx\n+\n+Cause:\n+\n+The computer name entered in mstsc does not match with any one of the \"hostnames\" attributes for target AADJ device. For example, AADJ device host name is the short name like device_1, but the computer name entered in mstsc is the FQDN like device_1.contoso.com.\n+\n+Try these solutions:\n+\n+There are multiple ways to resolve the issue:\n+1.\tModify the HOSTS entry on client machine, add an A DNS record that points the correct device name (confirm from AAD Device record) to the IP of target machine. Use that device name in mstsc.\n+2.\tCheck if the target machine is managed and if the hostname is set through Group Policy or MDM via the DNS Client PrimaryDnsSuffix value [ADMX_DnsClient Policy CSP | Microsoft Learn](/windows/client-management/mdm/policy-csp-admx-dnsclient#dns_primarydnssuffix). If this is set and is incorrect, it needs to be removed or set correctly. \n+3.\tWhen customer requires to use FQDN to connect but AAD Device name is a short name, login to the target machine via local admin, add a “**Primary DNS Suffix**” for their domain suffix. Detailed instructions:\n+- Navigate to **Advanced System Settings/System Properties** ->** Computer Name** tab -> select the \"**Change**\" button to rename the computer -> select \"**More**...\" under the existing computer name -> Type in your domain name and select **OK** -> Save and reboot.\n+- Once it’s done, we can RDP with FQDN directly and no need to modify the HOSTS entry.\n+\n+> [!NOTE]\n+> In such case, when Primary DNS Suffix is added, the Device-Sync scheduled task will be triggered which adding the FQDN into AAD device \"hostnames\" attributes. This is why it will resolve the issue.\n+\n+\n ### MFA sign-in method required\n \n You might see the following error message when you initiate a remote desktop connection to your device: \"The sign-in method you're trying to use isn't allowed. Try a different sign-in method or contact your system administrator.\""
}. Please summarise it in a few sentences, using UK grammar and ensure the response is formatted for markdown. Do not start the response with here is summary.","role":"user"}
ai_summary.Response:
This commit addresses a specific error encountered when signing into Windows virtual machines with Azure AD: `AADSTS293004: The target-device identifier in the request xxx was not found in the tenant xxx`.

The issue arises when the hostname used in the Remote Desktop Connection (mstsc) client does not precisely match the hostname registered for the Azure AD joined device. The update provides a comprehensive set of solutions, including modifying the HOSTS file, checking Group Policy or MDM settings for the DNS Client's `PrimaryDnsSuffix`, and crucially, instructs how to correctly set the "Primary DNS Suffix" on the target machine to align the FQDN with the Azure AD device record, thereby resolving the connection problem.

usage constraints and other service limits for the Microsoft Entra service.\n \n | Category | Limit |\n | --- | --- |\n-| Tenants |
  • A single user can belong to a maximum of 500 Microsoft Entra tenants as a member or a guest.
  • Create a maximum of 200 tenants.
  • Limit of 300 [license-based subscriptions](/microsoft-365/commerce/licenses/subscriptions-and-licenses) (such as Microsoft 365 subscriptions) per tenant |\n-| Domains |
  • You can add no more than 5,000 managed domain names.
  • If you set up all of your domains for federation with on-premises Active Directory, you can add no more than 2,500 domain names in each tenant. |\n-|Resources |
    • By default, a maximum of 50,000 Microsoft Entra resources can be created in a single tenant by users of the Microsoft Entra ID Free edition. If you have at least one verified domain, the default Microsoft Entra service quota for your organization is extended to 300,000 Microsoft Entra resources.
      The Microsoft Entra service quota for organizations created by self-service sign-up remains 50,000 Microsoft Entra resources, even after you perform an internal admin takeover and the organization is converted to a managed tenant with at least one verified domain. This service limit is unrelated to the pricing tier limit of 500,000 resources on the Microsoft Entra pricing page.
      To go beyond the default quota, you must contact Microsoft Support.
    • A non-admin user can create no more than 250 Microsoft Entra resources. Both active resources and deleted resources that are available to restore count toward this quota. Only deleted Microsoft Entra resources that were deleted fewer than 30 days ago are available to restore. Deleted Microsoft Entra resources that are no longer available to restore count toward this quota at a value of one-quarter for 30 days.
      If you have developers who are likely to repeatedly exceed this quota in the course of their regular duties, you can [create and assign a custom role](~/identity/role-based-access-control/quickstart-app-registration-limits.md) with permission to create a limitless number of app registrations.
    • Resource limitations apply to all directory objects in a given Microsoft Entra tenant, including users, groups, applications, and service principals.
    |\n+| Tenants |
    • A single user can belong to a maximum of 500 Microsoft Entra tenants as a member or a guest.
    • Create a maximum of 200 tenants.
    • Limit of 300 [license-based subscriptions](/microsoft-365/commerce/licenses/subscriptions-and-licenses) (such as Microsoft 365 subscriptions) per tenant.
    |\n+| Domains |
    • You can add no more than 5,000 managed domain names.
    • If you set up all of your domains for federation with on-premises Active Directory, you can add no more than 2,500 domain names in each tenant.
    |\n+| Resources |
    • By default, a maximum of 50,000 Microsoft Entra resources can be created in a single tenant by users of the Microsoft Entra ID Free edition. If you have at least one verified domain, the default Microsoft Entra service quota for your organization is extended to 300,000 Microsoft Entra resources.
      The Microsoft Entra service quota for organizations created by self-service sign-up remains 50,000 Microsoft Entra resources, even after you perform an internal admin takeover and the organization is converted to a managed tenant with at least one verified domain. This service limit is unrelated to the pricing tier limit of 500,000 resources on the Microsoft Entra pricing page.
      To go beyond the default quota, you must contact Microsoft Support.
    • A non-admin user can create no more than 250 Microsoft Entra resources. Both active resources and deleted resources that are available to restore count toward this quota. Only deleted Microsoft Entra resources that were deleted fewer than 30 days ago are available to restore. Deleted Microsoft Entra resources that are no longer available to restore count toward this quota at a value of one-quarter for 30 days.
      If you have developers who are likely to repeatedly exceed this quota in the course of their regular duties, you can [create and assign a custom role](~/identity/role-based-access-control/quickstart-app-registration-limits.md) with permission to create a limitless number of app registrations.
    • Resource limitations apply to all directory objects in a given Microsoft Entra tenant, including users, groups, applications, and service principals.
    |\n | Schema extensions |
    • String-type extensions can have a maximum of 256 characters.
    • Binary-type extensions are limited to 256 bytes.
    • Only 100 extension values, across *all* types and *all* applications, can be written to any single Microsoft Entra resource.
    • Only User, Group, TenantDetail, Device, Application, and ServicePrincipal entities can be extended with string-type or binary-type single-valued attributes.
    • Only the \"equals\" operator is supported for DateTime-type extensions. Range operators like \"greater than\" or \"less than\" are not supported.
    |\n | Applications |
    • A maximum of 100 users and service principals can be owners of a single application.
    • A user, group, or service principal can have a maximum of 1,500 app role assignments. The limitation is on the assigned service principal, user, or group across all app roles and not on the number of assignments of a single app role. This limit includes app role assignments where the resource service principal has been soft-deleted.
    • A user can have credentials configured for a maximum of 48 apps using password-based single sign-on. This limit only applies for credentials configured when the user is directly assigned the app, not when the user is a member of a group that is assigned.
    • A group can have credentials configured for a maximum of 48 apps using password-based single sign-on.
    • See additional limits in [Validation differences by supported account types](~/identity-platform/supported-accounts-validation.md).
    |\n |Application manifest |A maximum of 1,200 entries can be added to the application manifest.
    See additional limits in [Validation differences by supported account types](~/identity-platform/supported-accounts-validation.md). |\n-| Groups |
    • A non-admin user can create a maximum of 250 groups in a Microsoft Entra organization. Any Microsoft Entra admin who can manage groups in the organization can also create an unlimited number of groups (up to the Microsoft Entra object limit). If you assign a role to a user to remove the limit for that user, assign a less privileged, built-in role such as User Administrator or Groups Administrator.
    • A Microsoft Entra organization can have a maximum of 15,000 dynamic groups (including those originating from Microsoft Entra entitlement management automatic assignment policies) and dynamic administrative units combined.
    • A maximum of 500 [role-assignable groups](~/identity/role-based-access-control/groups-concept.md) can be created in a single Microsoft Entra organization (tenant).
    • A maximum of 100 users can be owners of a single group.
    • There is a limit of 1010 groups per token allowed for [Entra Kerberos](/troubleshoot/windows-server/windows-security/logging-on-user-account-fails).
    • Any number of Microsoft Entra resources can be members of a single group.
    • A user can be a member of any number of groups. When security groups are being used in combination with SharePoint Online, a user can be a part of 2,047 security groups in total. This includes both direct and indirect group memberships. When this limit is exceeded, authentication and search results become unpredictable.
    • Starting with Microsoft Entra Connect v2.0, the V2 endpoint is the default API. The number of members in a group that you can synchronize from your on-premises Active Directory to Microsoft Entra ID by using Microsoft Entra Connect is limited to 250,000 members. For more information, see [Microsoft Entra Connect Sync V2](../identity/hybrid/connect/how-to-connect-sync-endpoint-api-v2.md).
    • When you select a list of groups, you can assign a group expiration policy to a maximum of 500 Microsoft 365 groups. There's no limit when the policy is applied to all Microsoft 365 groups.

    At this time, the following scenarios are supported with nested groups:
    • One group can be added as a member of another group, and you can achieve group nesting.
    • Group membership claims. When an app is configured to receive group membership claims in the token, nested groups in which the signed-in user is a member are included.
    • Conditional Access (when a Conditional Access policy has a group scope).
    • Restricting access to self-serve password reset.
    • Restricting which users can do Microsoft Entra join and device registration.

    The following scenarios are *not* supported with nested groups:
    • App role assignment, for both access and provisioning. Assigning groups to an app is supported, but any groups nested within the directly assigned group won't have access.
    • Group-based licensing (assigning a license automatically to all members of a group).
    • Microsoft 365 Groups.
    |\n-| Application Proxy |
    • A maximum of 500 transactions\\* per second per Application Proxy application.
    • A maximum of 750 transactions per second for the Microsoft Entra organization.

      \\*A transaction is defined as a single HTTP request and response for a unique resource. When clients are throttled, they receive a 429 response (too many requests). Transaction metrics are collected on each connector and can be monitored using performance counters under the object name `Microsoft Entra private network connector`. |\n+| Groups |
      • A non-admin user can create a maximum of 250 groups in a Microsoft Entra organization. Any Microsoft Entra admin who can manage groups in the organization can also create an unlimited number of groups (up to the Microsoft Entra object limit). If you assign a role to a user to remove the limit for that user, assign a less privileged, built-in role such as User Administrator or Groups Administrator.
      • A Microsoft Entra organization can have a maximum of 15,000 dynamic groups (including those originating from Microsoft Entra entitlement management automatic assignment policies) and dynamic administrative units combined.
      • A maximum of 500 [role-assignable groups](~/identity/role-based-access-control/groups-concept.md) can be created in a single Microsoft Entra organization (tenant).
      • A maximum of 100 users can be owners of a single group.
      • There is a limit of 1010 groups per token allowed for [Entra Kerberos](/troubleshoot/windows-server/windows-security/logging-on-user-account-fails).
      • Any number of Microsoft Entra resources can be members of a single group.
      • If a user (or group) is a member of more than 2,048 groups (direct and nested), their access might be blocked. This limit applies to both direct and nested group memberships. See [Users, groups, and workload identities assignments in Conditional Access](~/identity/conditional-access/concept-conditional-access-users-groups.md).
      • A user can be a member of any number of groups. The following service-specific limits apply when group memberships are used in authentication or authorization (including direct and indirect memberships):
        • SharePoint Online: When security groups are used with SharePoint Online, a user can be a part of up to 2,047 security groups in total, including direct and indirect membership. When this limit is exceeded, authentication and search results can become unpredictable. See [SharePoint limits](/office365/servicedescriptions/sharepoint-online-service-description/sharepoint-online-limits).
        • SAML tokens: If optional groups claims are enabled, up to 150 group memberships (including nested groups) are included in SAML assertions. If a user is in more than 150 groups, the groups claim is omitted and an overage claim is sent instead. See [Configure optional claims](~/identity-platform/optional-claims.md) and the [SAML token claims reference](~/identity-platform/reference-saml-tokens.md#claims-in-saml-tokens) for implementation guidance.
        • JWT/OIDC tokens: If optional groups claims are enabled, up to 200 group memberships (including nested groups) are included in JWT tokens. If a user is in more than 200 groups, the groups claim is omitted and an overage claim is sent instead. See [Configure optional claims](~/identity-platform/optional-claims.md) and the [Access token claims reference](~/identity-platform/access-token-claims-reference.md#payload-claims) for implementation guidance.
        • Conditional Access policies: Policy evaluation supports up to 4,096 group memberships per user (direct and indirect). When this limit is exceeded, policy enforcement might fail. See [Users, groups, and workload identities assignments in Conditional Access](~/identity/conditional-access/concept-conditional-access-users-groups.md).
      • Starting with Microsoft Entra Connect v2.0, the V2 endpoint is the default API. The number of members in a group that you can synchronize from your on-premises Active Directory to Microsoft Entra ID by using Microsoft Entra Connect is limited to 250,000 members. For more information, see [Microsoft Entra Connect Sync V2](../identity/hybrid/connect/how-to-connect-sync-endpoint-api-v2.md).
      • When you select a list of groups, you can assign a group expiration policy to a maximum of 500 Microsoft 365 groups. There's no limit when the policy is applied to all Microsoft 365 groups.

      At this time, the following scenarios are supported with nested groups:
      • One group can be added as a member of another group, and you can achieve group nesting.
      • Group membership claims. When an app is configured to receive group membership claims in the token, nested groups in which the signed-in user is a member are included.
      • Conditional Access (when a Conditional Access policy has a group scope).
      • Restricting access to self-serve password reset.
      • Restricting which users can do Microsoft Entra join and device registration.

      The following scenarios are not supported with nested groups:
      • App role assignment, for both access and provisioning. Assigning groups to an app is supported, but any groups nested within the directly assigned group won't have access.
      • Group-based licensing (assigning a license automatically to all members of a group).
      • Microsoft 365 Groups.
      |\n+| Application Proxy |
      • A maximum of 500 transactions* per second per Application Proxy application.
      • A maximum of 750 transactions per second for the Microsoft Entra organization.

      *A transaction is defined as a single HTTP request and response for a unique resource. When clients are throttled, they receive a 429 response (too many requests). Transaction metrics are collected on each connector and can be monitored using performance counters under the object name `Microsoft Entra private network connector`. |\n | Access Panel |There's no limit to the number of applications per user that can be displayed in the Access Panel, regardless of the number of assigned licenses. |\n | Reports | A maximum of 1,000 rows can be viewed or downloaded in any report. Any additional data is truncated. |\n | Administrative units |
      • A Microsoft Entra resource can be a member of no more than 30 administrative units.
      • There isn't a specific limit for the number of administrative units in a tenant, but you can only have a maximum of 100 restricted management administrative units in a tenant.
      • A Microsoft Entra organization can have a maximum of 15,000 dynamic groups (including those originating from Microsoft Entra entitlement management automatic assignment policies) and dynamic administrative units combined.
      |" } ]. Please summarise it in a few sentences, using UK grammar and ensure the response is formatted for markdown. Do not start the response with here is summary.","role":"user"}
ai_summary.Response: This commit updates the documentation for Microsoft Entra service limits and restrictions. The primary changes involve adjusting the `ms.date` metadata in two files and significantly expanding the details regarding group membership limits and their implications across various Microsoft Entra features, including SAML tokens, JWT/OIDC tokens, and Conditional Access policies.

The [Access Review Agent](../id-governance/access-review-agent.md) with [Microsoft Entra ID Governance](../id-governance/identity-governance-overview.md) delivers insights and recommendations so reviewers can complete their work through a simple conversation, right inside Microsoft Teams.\n \n+| Attribute | Description |\n+|---------------------|------------ |\n+| Identity | Runs with identity of the administrator who configured the agent. Final decisions as part of the Microsoft Teams conversation use the reviewer's identity. |\n+| Licenses | [Microsoft Entra ID Governance or Microsoft Entra Suite](../id-governance/licensing-fundamentals.md) |\n+| Permissions | Get details for access reviews

The agent evaluates your current policy configuration against Microsoft best practices and Zero Trust principles.\n \n-**Key capabilities:**\n-- Identifies users and applications not covered by Conditional Access policies\n-- Recommends policies for multifactor authentication enforcement or device-based controls (compliance, app protection, domain-joined devices)\n-- Detects and helps block legacy authentication and device code flows\n-- Creates new policies in report-only mode for safe testing\n-- Builds a phased rollout plan for policy implementation\n-\n | Attribute | Description |\n |---------------------|------------ |\n-| Trigger | Runs every 24 hours or can be triggered manually |\n-| Permissions | Reviews policy configuration, creates new policies in report-only mode, suggests policy changes requiring approval |\n-| Identity | Runs with the permissions of the administrator who configured the agent |\n-| Products | [Microsoft Entra Conditional Access](/entra/identity/conditional-access/), [Security Copilot](/copilot/security/microsoft-security-copilot) |\n-| Plugins | [Microsoft Entra](/entra/fundamentals/copilot-security-entra) |\n-| Role requirements | [Security Administrator](../identity/role-based-access-control/permissions-reference.md#security-administrator) or [Global Administrator](../identity/role-based-access-control/permissions-reference.md#global-administrator) to configure the agent |\n+| Identity | Runs with the identity of the administrator who configured the agent |\n+| Licenses | [Microsoft Entra ID P1](licensing.md) |\n+| Permissions | Review policy configuration

@@\n+---\n+title: How to Customize Global Secure Access Block Page\n+description: Use custom block pages to display organization-specific messaging internet access policies block users from accessing websites.\n+author: fgomulka\n+ms.author: frankgomulka\n+ms.topic: how-to\n+ms.service: global-secure-access\n+ms.date: 09/24/2025\n+ms.reviewer: kenwith\n+ai-usage: ai-assisted\n+---\n+\n+# How to customize Global Secure Access block page (preview)\n+\n+Use custom block pages to display organization-specific messaging internet access policies block users from accessing websites.\n+\n+## Prerequisites\n+\n+- Configure [Transport Layer Security (TLS) inspection](./how-to-transport-layer-security.md).\n+- Configure [web content filtering](./how-to-configure-web-content-filtering.md) and/or [threat intelligence filtering](./how-to-configure-threat-intelligence.md).\n+- Ensure you have the [Global Secure Access Administrator role](/azure/active-directory/roles/permissions-reference) or equivalent role in Microsoft Entra ID assigned.\n+\n+## Overview\n+\n+The custom block page empowers you to customize the default body of the page from, \"It's been restricted by your organization.\" you configure and preview tailored messaging to coincide with your organization's style guide when internet access policies block a user's request to access an internet resource.\n+\n+## Configure a custom block page\n+\n+1. Navigate to **Global Secure Access** > **Settings** > **Session management** > **Custom Block Page**\n+2. Switch **Custom body message** to **On**.\n+3. Configure the Customized body message you would prefer. For example, `Your admin at Contoso has blocked your access.`\n+4. (Optional) Paste one or multiple clickable links via limited markdown language (for example, `[click here](https://bing.com)`).\n+5. Preview the customized message with the **Preview** button.\n+6. Select **Save** to save the custom block page.\n+\n+![Screenshot showing the preview experience in the admin portal](media/how-to-customize-block-page/custom-block-preview.png)\n+\n+> [!NOTE]\n+> A known transient issue in public preview could result in the configuration failing. While the Microsoft team works on a fix, the current mitigation is to reconfigure the custom block page and try again.\n+\n+## Verify the block page\n+\n+1. From a device with the Global Secure Access client installed and the Internet Access traffic forwarding profile enabled, attempt to navigate to a site that your policy blocks.\n+2. Observe the block experience and confirm the custom messaging displays.\n+\n+![Screenshot showing end user experience of the custom block page](media/how-to-customize-block-page/custom-block.png)\n+\n+## Notes and limitations\n+\n+- The Custom body message is limited to 1024 Unicode (utf-8) characters.\n+- Changes to a custom block page might take a few minutes to propagate to active sessions.\n+- Custom block pages appear for TLS inspected traffic only.\n+- A known transient issue in public preview could result in the configuration failing. While Microsoft team works on a fix, the current mitigation is to reconfigure the custom block page and try again.\n+- Ensure any contact information you publish complies with your organization's privacy policies.\n+\n+## Next steps\n+\n+- If you need features beyond the preview's capabilities (richer templates, localization, or analytics), collect feedback and request expanded preview access from the product team.\n+- For guidance on configuring web content filtering, see [Configure web content filtering](./how-to-configure-web-content-filtering.md).\n+- For guidance on configuring threat intelligence, see [Configure threat intelligence](./how-to-configure-threat-intelligence.md).\n\\ No newline at end of file" }, { "sha": "46396e4f3441cd124ca8d57b0dd9ae6634d05205", "filename": ai_summary.Response: This commit introduces a new article on customising the block page for Microsoft Global Secure Access, along with its associated images and an update to the `toc.yml` to include it. It also refines the documentation for the Access Review Agent, clarifying role requirements and adding a note about its integration with Security Copilot. Further updates include a minor correction to an API URL in the Global Secure Access documentation, adjustments to the token lifetime description for Primary Refresh Tokens, and a precision update to the required role for adding protected actions in Microsoft Entra ID. Finally, the date has been updated for the Copilot and Entra Agents overview document.

ai_summary.Response: This commit updates the documentation for the access review agent. It clarifies the consumption of Security Compute Units (SCUs) per access review, changing the average from one SCU to 4.5 SCU for twenty decisions. This adjustment accounts for the agent's insight gathering, recommendation generation, and the reviewer's conversational interaction.

    "patch": "@@ -3,12 +3,11 @@ title: Rotate signing keys\n description: Learn how to rotate Microsoft Entra Verified ID signing keys.\n documentationCenter: ''\n author: barclayn\n-manager: femila\n+manager: pmwongera\n ms.service: entra-verified-id\n ms.topic: how-to\n ms.date: 01/31/2025\n ms.author: barclayn\n-\n #Customer intent: As an administrator, I'm looking for information on how to rotate signing keys.\n ---\n \n@@ -18,8 +17,6 @@ In this article, we review the steps to rotate your Microsoft Entra Verified ID\n \n ## Prerequisites\n \n-- Verified ID authority is [manually onboarded](verifiable-credentials-configure-tenant.md), and the signing keys are in your own Azure Key Vault instance. [Quick setup](verifiable-credentials-configure-tenant-quick.md) uses a shared signing key, managed by Microsoft, that you can't rotate yourself.\n-- The admin user performing key rotation must have [permission to the keys](verifiable-credentials-configure-tenant.md) in Key Vault.\n \n ## Rotate the signing keys\n \n@@ -69,5 +66,3 @@ For example, say you have 12 keys in Key Vault and you want Verified ID to not l\n You shouldn't use the rotate feature in Key Vault's admin portal. Verified ID performs more tasks when it calls the /signingKeys/rotate API than just rotating the key in Key Vault.\n \n ## Next steps\n-\n-- [Tutorial for issuing a verifiable credential](verifiable-credentials-configure-issuer.md)\n\\ No newline at end of file"

    "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/6da18135b57c75860b4eeb0a0732b9db3800de06/docs%2Fverified-id%2Fhowto-verifiable-credentials-partner-au10tix.md",

    "patch": "@@ -1,81 +0,0 @@\n----\n-title: Configure Verified ID by AU10TIX as your Identity Verification Partner \n-description: This article shows you the steps you need to follow to configure AU10TIX as your identity verification partner.\n-author: barclayn\n-manager: femila\n-ms.service: entra-verified-id\n-ms.topic: how-to\n-ms.date: 01/17/2025\n-ms.author: barclayn\n-# Customer intent: As a developer, I'm looking for information about the open standards that are supported by Microsoft Entra Verified ID.\n----\n-\n-# Configure Verified ID by AU10TIX as your Identity Verification Partner\n-\n-In this article, we cover the steps needed to integrate Microsoft Entra Verified ID with [AU10TIX](https://www.au10tix.com/). AU10TIX is an automated solution for the verification of ID documents + biometrics. AU10TIX supports the verification of documents in over 190 regions reading documents in their regional languages.\n-\n-To learn more about AU10TIX and its complete set of solutions, visit https://www.au10tix.com/.\n-\n-## Prerequisites\n-\n- You need to meet the following requirements before you can continue with the steps in this article:\n-\n-- A tenant [configured](verifiable-credentials-configure-tenant.md) for Microsoft Entra Verified ID service.\n-    - If you don't have an existing tenant, you can [create an Azure account for free](https://azure.microsoft.com/free/?WT.mc_id=A261C142F).\n-- You first need to complete the onboarding process with Au10tix.\n-    - To create a AU10TIX account, submit the form on this [page](https://www.au10tix.com/solutions/verifiable-credentials/).\n-\n-\n->[!IMPORTANT]\n-> Before you proceed, you must have a URL from Au10Tix for users to be issued Verified IDs. If you don't have it, follow up with Au10Tix before you attempt to follow the steps in this article.\n-\n-## Scenario description\n-\n-When onboarding users you can remove the need for error prone manual onboarding steps by using Verified ID with A10TIX account onboarding. Verified IDs can be used to digitally onboard employees, students, citizens, or others to securely access resources and services. For example, rather than an employee needing to go to a central office to activate an employee badge, they can use a Verified ID to verify their identity to activate a badge that is delivered to them remotely. Rather than a citizen receiving a code they must redeem to access governmental services, they can use a Verified ID to prove their identity and gain access. Learn more about [account onboarding](./plan-verification-solution.md#account-onboarding).\n-\n-\n-\n-:::image type=\"content\" source=\"media/verified-id-partner-au10tix/vc-solution-architecture-diagram.png\" alt-text=\"Diagram of the verifiable credential solution.\":::\n-\n-\n-## Configure your Application to use AU10TIX Verified ID\n-\n-For incorporating identity verification into your Apps, using AU10TIX  \"Government Issued ID - Global\" Verified ID follow these steps:\n-\n-### Part 1\n-\n-As a developer you can share these steps with your tenant administrator to obtain the verification request URL, and body for your application or website to request Verified IDs from your users.\n-\n-1. Go to [Microsoft Entra admin center -> Verified ID](https://entra.microsoft.com/#view/Microsoft_AAD_DecentralizedIdentity/ResourceOverviewBlade). \n-\n-   >[!NOTE]\n-   > Make sure this tenant is the one where you set up Verified ID per the prerequisites.\n-\n-1. Select QuickStart > Verification Request > [Start](https://entra.microsoft.com/#view/Microsoft_AAD_DecentralizedIdentity/QuickStartVerifierBlade)\n-1. Choose **Select Issuer**.\n-1. Look for AU10TIX in the **Search/select issuers** drop-down.\n-\n-   :::image type=\"content\" source=\"./media/verified-id-partner-au10tix/select-issuers.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot of the portal section used to choose issuers.\":::\n-\n-1. Check the **Government Issued ID – Global** or other credential type.\n-1. Select **Add** and then select **Review**.\n-1. Download the request body and Copy/paste POST API request URL.\n-\n-### Part 2\n-\n-As a developer you now have the request URL and body from your tenant admin, follow these steps to update your application or website:\n-\n-1. To request Verified IDs from your users, include the request URL and body in your application or website. \n-   >[!Note]\n-   >If you are using [one of the sample apps](https://aka.ms/vcsample), you'll need to replace the contents of the `presentation_request_config.json` with the request body obtained in [Part 1](#part-1). The sample code overwrites the `trustedIssuers` values with `IssuerAuthority` value from `appsettings.json`. Copy the `trustedIssuers` value from the payload to `IssuerAuthority` in `appsettings.json` file.\n-1. Be sure to replace the values for the **URL**, **state**, and **api-key** with your respective values.\n-1. [Grant permissions](verifiable-credentials-configure-tenant.md#grant-permissions-to-get-access-tokens) to your app to obtain access token for the Verified ID service request service principal.\n-\n-## Test the user flow\n-\n-User flow is specific to your application or website. However if you use one of the sample apps follow the steps outlined as part of the [sample app's documentation](https://aka.ms/vcsample).\n-\n-## Next steps\n-\n-- [Verifiable credentials admin API](admin-api.md)\n-- [Request Service REST API issuance specification](issuance-request-api.md)"
  },

    "patch": "@@ -1,72 +0,0 @@\n----\n-title: Configure LexisNexis Risk Solutions as an identity verification partner using Verified ID\n-description: This article shows you the steps you need to follow to configure LexisNexis as your identity verification partner.\n-author: barclayn\n-manager: femila\n-ms.service: entra-verified-id\n-ms.topic: how-to\n-ms.date: 01/17/2025\n-ms.author: barclayn\n-# Customer intent: As a developer, I'm looking for information about the open standards that are supported by Microsoft Entra Verified ID.\n----\n-\n-# Configure Verified ID with LexisNexis as your Identity Verification Partner\n-\n-You can use Microsoft Entra Verified ID with LexisNexis Risk Solutions to enable faster onboarding by replacing some human interactions. Verifiable Credentials (VCs) can be used to onboard employees, students, citizens, or others to access services.\n-\n-## Prerequisites\n-\n-- A tenant [configured](verifiable-credentials-configure-tenant.md) for Microsoft Entra Verified ID service.\n-    - If you don't have an existing tenant, you can [create an Azure account for free](https://azure.microsoft.com/free/?WT.mc_id=A261C142F).\n-- Your tenant should first complete the LexisNexis onboarding process.\n-    - Create a LexisNexis account, you can request a [demo](https://solutions.risk.lexisnexis.com/did-microsoft). Expect response from your LexisNexis Risk Solutions within 48 hours.\n-\n->[!IMPORTANT]\n-> Before you proceed, you must first have the URL from LexisNexis risk solutions for users to be issued Verified IDs. If you don't receive it, follow up with LexisNexis before you attempt to follow these steps.\n-\n-## Scenario description\n-\n-Verifiable Credentials can be used to onboard employees, students, citizens, or others to access services. For example, rather than an employee needing to go to a central office to activate an employee badge, they can use a verifiable credential to verify their identity to activate a badge that is delivered to them remotely. Rather than a citizen receiving a code they must redeem to access governmental services, they can use a VC to prove their identity and gain access. Learn more about [account onboarding](./plan-verification-solution.md#account-onboarding). \n-\n-\n-:::image type=\"content\" source=\"media/verified-id-partner-au10tix/vc-solution-architecture-diagram.png\" alt-text=\"Diagram of the verifiable credential solution.\":::\n-\n-## Configure your application to use LexisNexis\n-\n-To incorporate identity verification into your Apps using LexisNexis Verified ID, follow these steps.\n-\n-### Part 1\n-\n-As a developer you need to share the steps in this section with your tenant administrator. These instructions help them get the verification request URL, and application body or website to request verifiable credentials from your users.\n-\n-1. Go to [Microsoft Entra admin center -> Verified ID](https://entra.microsoft.com/#view/Microsoft_AAD_DecentralizedIdentity/ResourceOverviewBlade).\n-    >[!Note]\n-    > Make sure this is the tenant you set up for Verified ID per the pre-requisites.\n-1. Go to [Quickstart-> Verification Request -> Start](https://entra.microsoft.com/#view/Microsoft_AAD_DecentralizedIdentity/QuickStartVerifierBlade).\n-1. Select on **Select Issuer**.\n-1. Look for LexisNexis in the Search/select issuers drop-down. \n-   \n-   [ :::image type=\"content\" source=\"./media/verified-id-partner-lexisnexis/select-issuer.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot of the select issuer section of the portal showing LexisNexis as the choice.\":::](./media/verified-id-partner-lexisnexis/select-issuer.png#lightbox)\n-   \n-1. Check the credential type you discussed with LexisNexis Customer success manager for your specific needs.\n-1. Choose **Add** and then choose **Review**.\n-1. Download the request body and Copy/paste POST API request URL.\n-\n-### Part 2\n-\n-As a developer you now have the request URL and body from your tenant admin, follow these steps to update your application or website:\n-\n-1. To request Verified IDs from your users, include the request URL and body in your application or website. \n-   >[!Note]\n-   >If you are using [one of the sample apps](https://aka.ms/vcsample), you'll need to replace the contents of the `presentation_request_config.json` with the request body obtained in [Part 1](#part-1). The sample code overwrites the `trustedIssuers` values with `IssuerAuthority` value from `appsettings.json`. Copy the `trustedIssuers` value from the payload to `IssuerAuthority` in `appsettings.json` file.\n-1. Replace the values for the **URL**, **state**, and **api-key** with your respective values.\n-1. Grant your app [permissions](verifiable-credentials-configure-tenant.md#grant-permissions-to-get-access-tokens) to obtain an access token for the Verified ID service request service principal.\n-\n-## Test the user flow\n-\n-User flow is specific to your application or website. However if you are using [one of the sample apps](https://aka.ms/vcsample) follow the steps here - [Run the test the sample app](https://aka.ms/vcsample)\n-\n-## Next steps\n-\n-- [Verifiable credentials admin API](admin-api.md)\n-- [Request Service REST API issuance specification](issuance-request-api.md)"
  },

    "patch": "@@ -1,70 +0,0 @@\n----\n-title: Configure Verified ID by IDEMIA as your identity verification partner \n-description: This article shows you the steps you need to follow to configure IDEMIA as your identity verification partner.\n-author: barclayn\n-manager: femila\n-ms.service: entra-verified-id\n-ms.topic: how-to\n-ms.date: 04/30/2025\n-ms.author: barclayn\n-# Customer intent: As a developer, I'm looking for information about the open standards that are supported by Microsoft Entra Verified ID.\n----\n-\n-# Configure Verified ID by IDEMIA as your identity verification partner\n-\n-In this article, we cover the steps needed to integrate Microsoft Entra Verified ID (Verified ID) with [IDEMIA](https://www.idemia.com/).\n-\n-## Prerequisites\n-\n-Before you can continue, you need to meet the following requirements: \n-\n-- A tenant configured with Verified ID.\n-   - If you don't have an existing tenant, you can create an Azure account for free. \n-- You need to first complete the onboarding process with IDEMIA. \n-   - Register on the IDEMIA Experience Portal where you can create your own Microsoft verifiable credential application with a few steps low code integration. \n-\n->[!IMPORTANT]\n->Before you can proceed, you must have already received a URL from IDEMIA. If you haven't yet received it, follow up with IDEMIA before you try the steps documented below.\n-\n-\n-## Scenario description\n-\n-Verified ID users can have their identity verified using IDEMIA's identity document capture and verification.\n-The Identity proofing process is completed using biometric and document capture via the users' smartphones. Once a user submits their data, biometric and document data is extracted and verified against one another, or against an authoritative data source such as a national identity database or a trusted system of record. Counter-fraud and high-risk profile verification could also be performed for additional assurance. \n-\n-The result is a trusted user identity that gives service providers the assurance they need to proceed with customer onboarding. \n-\n-\n-After verification, users are issued a reusable identity credential, which expedites the onboarding process for employees, partners, and customers​.\n-\n-\n-## Configure IDEMIA as your identity verification proofing solution\n-\n-To configure IDEMIA as your identity verification proofing solution, follow these steps:\n-\n-1. In the Microsoft Entra admin center, locate **Verified ID** in the left hand menu and select **Overview**.\n-1. Select **Explore** and select **Verification request**.\n-1. Choose **Select issuer(s)** and select **Select first issuer**.\n-1. Look for **IDEMIA** in the search/select issuers drop down.\n-1. Select **VerifiedIdentity** as the credential type.\n-1. Select **Add** and then select **Review**.\n-1. Download the request body and copy/paste the POST API request URL\n-\n-## Developer steps\n-\n-As a developer you now have the request URL and body from your tenant admin, follow these steps to update your application or website:\n-\n-1. Add the request URL and body to your application or website to request Verified IDs from your users.\n-    >[!IMPORTANT]\n-    >If you are using one of the sample apps, you'll need to replace the contents of the presentation_request_config.json with the request body obtained in Part 1. The sample code overwrites the trustedIssuers values with IssuerAuthority value from ```appsettings.json```. Copy the trustedIssuers value from the payload to IssuerAuthority in ```appsettings.json``` file.\n-2. Replace the **URL** and **api key** values with your own values.\n-3. [Grant permissions](verifiable-credentials-configure-tenant.md#grant-permissions-to-get-access-tokens) to your app so it can obtain an access token for the Verified ID service request service principal.\n-\n-## Test the user flow\n-\n-User flow is specific to your application or website. However, if you are using one of the sample apps follow the steps outlined as part of the sample app's documentation.\n-\n-## Next steps\n-\n-- [Verifiable credentials admin API](admin-api.md)\n-- [Request Service REST API issuance specification](issuance-request-api.md)"
  },

With verifiable credentials and Onfido you can verify a person’s identity while respecting privacy.     "sha": "6a3bd9ec36d5f23e201b34818629a35421678655",
    "filename": "docs/verified-id/partner-vu.md",
    "status": "removed",
    "additions": 0,
    "deletions": 97,
    "changes": 97,
    "blob_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/blob/6da18135b57c75860b4eeb0a0732b9db3800de06/docs%2Fverified-id%2Fpartner-vu.md",
    "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/6da18135b57c75860b4eeb0a0732b9db3800de06/docs%2Fverified-id%2Fpartner-vu.md",
    "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fverified-id%2Fpartner-vu.md?ref=6da18135b57c75860b4eeb0a0732b9db3800de06",
    "patch": "@@ -1,97 +0,0 @@\n----\r\n-title: Configure Microsoft Entra Verified ID with VU Security Digital Identity as your Identity Verification Partner\r\n-description: Configure Microsoft Entra Verified ID with VU Digital Identity as your Identity Verification Partner.\r\n-author: gargi-sinha\r\n-manager: martinco\r\n-ms.service: entra-verified-id\r\n-ms.topic: how-to\r\n-ms.date: 06/18/2024\r\n-ms.author: gasinh\r\n-# Customer intent: As a developer, I'm looking for information about the open standards supported by Microsoft Entra Verified ID.\r\n----\r\n-\r\n-# Configure Microsoft Entra Verified ID with VU Security Digital Identity as your Identity Verification Partner\r\n-\r\n-In this article, learn to integrate [Microsoft Entra Verified ID](decentralized-identifier-overview.md) with [VU Security](https://www.vusecurity.com/) Digital Identity to create secure and frictionless digital experiences. Enhance biometric onboarding and verification scenarios throughout the lifecycle of citizens and organizations.\r\n-\r\n-Digital Identity has flexible onboarding, authentication, and verification processes on devices. It improves user experience and security without affecting business processes.\r\n-\r\n-## Prerequisites\r\n-\r\n-To get started, ensure the following prerequisites are met:\r\n-\r\n-- A tenant [configured](./verifiable-credentials-configure-tenant.md) for Microsoft Entra Verified ID.\r\n-\r\n-  - Use a tenant, or [create an Azure account](https://azure.microsoft.com/free/?WT.mc_id=A261C142F) for free.\r\n-\r\n-- Complete the Digital Identity onboarding process.\r\n-\r\n-- To create an account, go to [VU Security](https://www.vusecurity.com/) and select **Contact**.\r\n-\r\n-   >[!Important]\r\n-   >To proceed, use the VU Security-provided URL for users to be issued Verified IDs. \r\n-\r\n-## Scenario description\r\n-\r\n-Digital Identity is a link between users who need to access an application and applications that require secure access control, regardless of how users access the system.\r\n-\r\n-To enable faster and easier user onboarding, replace some human interactions with verifiable credentials. For a user to create or remotely access an account, enable Verified ID with Digital Identity. Verify identity without using vulnerable or complex passwords, or require users to be on-site.\r\n-\r\n-Learn more about [account onboarding](./plan-verification-solution.md#account-onboarding).\r\n-\r\n-In this account onboarding scenario, Digital Identity plays the Trusted ID proofing issuer role.\r\n-\r\n-   :::image type=\"content\" source=\"media/partner-vu/vc-solution-architecture-diagram.png\" alt-text=\"Diagram of the verifiable credential solution.\":::\r\n-\r\n-## Configure applications to use Digital Identity\r\n-\r\n-Incorporate Digital Identity into your apps.\r\n-\r\n-### Select issuer\r\n-\r\n-As a developer you can share these steps with your tenant administrator to obtain the verification request URL, and body for your application or website to request Verified IDs from your users.\r\n-\r\n-1. Go to the Microsoft Entra admin center - [**Verified ID**](https://entra.microsoft.com/#view/Microsoft_AAD_DecentralizedIdentity/ResourceOverviewBlade)\r\n-\r\n-   >[!TIP]\r\n-   >Confirm the tenant configured for Verified ID meets prerequisites.\r\n-\r\n-2. Go to **Quickstart**\r\n-3. Select **Verification Request**.\r\n-4. Select [**Start**](https://entra.microsoft.com/#view/Microsoft_AAD_DecentralizedIdentity/QuickStartVerifierBlade).\r\n-5. Select **Select Issuer**.\r\n-6. In Search, in the **Issuers** drop-down, find **VU Security**.\r\n-\r\n-   :::image type=\"content\" source=\"./media/partner-vu/select-issuers.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot of the portal section used to choose issuers.\":::\r\n-\r\n-7. Compare the **VUIdentityCard** credential with attributes such as firstname, lastname, number, country, region, gender, birth date, nationality. etc.\r\n-\r\n-   >[!NOTE]\r\n-   >Number attribute refers to a national ID. For example, the Documento Nacional de Identidad (DNI) in Argentina.\r\n-\r\n-8. Select **Add**.\r\n-9. Select **Review**.\r\n-10. Download the request body.\r\n-11. Copy/paste POST API request URL.\r\n-\r\n-### Update an application or website\r\n-\r\n-With the request URL and body from the tenant administrator, update your application or website.\r\n-\r\n-1. To request Verified IDs from your users, add the request URL and body to your application or website.\r\n-\r\n-   >[!NOTE]\r\n-   >If you're using [a sample app](https://aka.ms/vcsample), replace the contents of the `presentation_request_config.json` with the request body obtained in the previous instructions. The sample code overwrites the `trustedIssuers` values with `IssuerAuthority` value from `appsettings.json`.\r\n-\r\n-2. Copy the `trustedIssuers` value from the payload to `IssuerAuthority` in the `appsettings.json` file.\r\n-3. Replace the values for **url**, **state**, and **api-key** with your values.\r\n-4. To obtain an access token for the Verified ID service request Service Principal, [grant needed permissions](verifiable-credentials-configure-tenant.md#grant-permissions-to-get-access-tokens) for your app.\r\n-\r\n-## Test the user flow\r\n-\r\n-User flow is specific to your application or website. However, with a sample app, see [related documentation](https://aka.ms/vcsample).\r\n-\r\n-## Next steps\r\n-\r\n-- [Verifiable credentials admin API](admin-api.md)\r\n-- [Request Service REST API issuance specification](issuance-request-api.md)\r"
  },

    "patch": "@@ -3,7 +3,7 @@ title: Tutorial - Issue Microsoft Entra Verified ID credentials from an applicat\n description: In this tutorial, you learn how to issue verifiable credentials by using a sample app.\n ms.service: entra-verified-id\n author: barclayn\n-manager: femila\n+manager: pmwongera\n ms.author: barclayn\n ms.topic: tutorial\n ms.date: 04/30/2025"

Learn how to enable the Face Check add-on in your tenant by linking your Microsoft Azure subscription.\n ms.service: entra-verified-id\n author: barclayn\n-manager: femila\n+manager: pmwongera\n ms.author: barclayn\n ms.topic: concept-article\n ms.date: 04/30/2025"

    "sha": "efc23796ab93dc3cda33eec8034de9ad2e476eed",

    "patch": "@@ -2,10 +2,10 @@\n title: What's new for Microsoft Entra Verified ID\n description: Recent updates for Microsoft Entra Verified ID\n author: barclayn\n-manager: femila\n+manager: pmwongera\n ms.service: entra-verified-id\n ms.topic: whats-new\n-ms.date: 04/30/2025\n+ms.date: 09/23/2025\n ms.custom: references_regions\n ms.author: barclayn\n \n@@ -17,6 +17,17 @@ ms.author: barclayn\n \n This article lists the latest features, improvements, and changes in the Microsoft Entra Verified ID service.\n \n+\n+## September 2025\n+\n+- Entra Verified ID is supported on Microsoft GCC environments. \n+    \n+    >[!NOTE] \n+    > This is GCC only and not GCC High.\n+\n+- Updates to the IDV Partner Gallery\n+\n+\n ## January 2025\n \n - Instructions for [upgrading signing key](signing-key-upgrade.md) to become FIPS compliant.\n@@ -101,15 +112,15 @@ The `presentation_verified` callback from the Request Service API now returns wh\n \n ## June 2023\n \n-Tutorial for getting started with the Wallet Library demo on Android and iOS available [here](using-wallet-library.md).\n+Tutorial for getting started with the Wallet Library demo on Android and iOS is available in the [Wallet Library quickstart](using-wallet-library.md).\n \n ## May 2023\n \n - Wallet Library was announced at Build 2023 in session [Reduce fraud and improve engagement using Digital Wallets](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wtEzFqtsq8U). The Wallet Library enables customers to add verifiable credentials technology to their own mobile apps. The libraries are available for [Android](https://github.com/microsoft/entra-verifiedid-wallet-library-android/tree/dev) and [iOS](https://github.com/microsoft/entra-verifiedid-wallet-library-ios/tree/dev).\n \n ## April 2023\n \n-Instructions for setting up place of work verification on LinkedIn available [here](linkedin-employment-verification.md).\n+Instructions for setting up place of work verification on LinkedIn are available in [LinkedIn employment verification guidance](linkedin-employment-verification.md).\n \n ## March 2023\n \n@@ -135,7 +146,7 @@ Instructions for setting up place of work verification on LinkedIn available [he\n ## September 2022\n \n - The Request Service API now has [granular app permissions](verifiable-credentials-configure-tenant.md?#grant-permissions-to-get-access-tokens) and you can grant **VerifiableCredential.Create.IssueRequest** and **VerifiableCredential.Create.PresentRequest** separately to segregate duties of issuance and presentation to separate application. \n-- [IDV Partner Gallery](partner-gallery.md) now available in the documentation guiding you how to integrate with Microsoft's Identity Verification partners.\n+- [IDV Partner Gallery](idv-partners.md) now available in the documentation guiding you how to integrate with Microsoft's Identity Verification partners.\n - How-to guide for implementing the [presentation attestation flow](how-to-use-quickstart-presentation.md) that requires presenting a verifiable credential during issuance.\n \n ## August 2022"
  }
]. Please summarise it in a few sentences, using UK grammar and ensure the response is formatted for markdown. Do not start the response with here is summary."}
ai_summary.Response: This commit updates the documentation for Microsoft Entra Verified ID. It consolidates multiple partner pages into a single `idv-partners.md` file and redirects the old paths accordingly. Additionally, several files have had minor updates, including corrections to manager fields and slight rephrasing in the "What's New" section, along with the addition of new content regarding September 2025 updates.
